description: From Middle French volant, present participle of voler (“to fly”), from Latin volāre.

entries.meaning: (heraldry) Having extended wings as if flying.
(heraldry) Represented as unsupported in the air.

examples: Alexander the Great  […]  lanced himself in manner of a Star Volant in the Air, leaping out of the East into the West,  […]

entries.meaning: Moving quickly or lightly, as though flying; nimble.
examples: he turned to catch through the trees a flitting glimpse of her light dress, her volant attitude, as she sped silently and secretly back to the waiting group on the porch.
